cleaned_text: Johnson & Johnson |Type|[ISIN](/wiki/International_Securities_Identification_Number) [US4781601046](https://iw.toolforge.org/isin/?language=en&isin=US4781601046) [New Brunswick, New Jersey](/wiki/New_Brunswick,_New_Jersey), United States [Johnson and Johnson Plaza](/wiki/Johnson_and_Johnson_Plaza), [List of Johnson [multinational](/wiki/Multinational_corporation), [pharmaceutical](/wiki/Pharmaceutical_industry), and [medical technologies](/wiki/Medical_device) corporation headquartered in [New Brunswick, New Jersey](/wiki/New_Brunswick,_New_Jersey) and publicly traded on the [New York Stock Exchange](/wiki/New_York_Stock_Exchange). Its common stock is a component of the [Dow Jones Industrial Average](/wiki/Dow_Jones_Industrial_Average), and the company is ranked No. 40 on the 2023 [Fortune 500](/wiki/Fortune_500) list of the largest United States corporations. Johnson & Johnson has a global workforce of approximately 130,000 employees who are led by the company's current [chairman](/wiki/Chairman) and [chief executive officer](/wiki/Chief_executive_officer), [Joaquin Duato](/wiki/Joaquin_Duato). Johnson & Johnson was founded in 1886, by three brothers [Robert Wood Johnson](/wiki/Robert_Wood_Johnson_I), [James Wood [Edward Mead Johnson](/wiki/Edward_Mead_Johnson) selling ready-to-use sterile surgical dressings. In 2023, the company split off its consumer healthcare business group into a new publicly traded company, [Kenvue](/wiki/Kenvue). The company is exclusively focused on developing and producing [pharmaceutical](/wiki/Pharmaceutical_industry) prescription drugs and [medical device](/wiki/Medical_device) technologies. Johnson & Johnson is one of the world's most valuable companies and is one of only two U.S.-based companies that has a prime [credit rating](/wiki/Credit_rating) of AAA. [edit](/w/index.php?title=Johnson_%26_Johnson&action=edit§ion=2)] [Robert Wood Johnson](/wiki/Robert_Wood_Johnson_I) began his professional training at age 16 as a pharmaceutical apprentice at an apothecary run by his mother's cousin, James G. Wood, in Poughkeepsie, New York. [[3]](#cite_note-3) [[4]](#cite_note-Rebel-4): 12 Johnson co-founded his own company with [George Seabury](/wiki/George_J._Seabury) in 1873. The New York-based Seabury & Johnson became known for its medicated plasters. [[5]](#cite_note-bio_dictionary-5): 675 [[4]](#cite_note-Rebel-4): 15 Robert Wood Johnson represented the company at the [1876 World's Fair.](/wiki/Centennial_Exposition) [[6]](#cite_note-6) [[7]](#cite_note-7) There a new procedure: antiseptic surgery. [[4]](#cite_note-Rebel-4): 31 Johnson parted ways with his business partner Seabury in 1885. [[4]](#cite_note-Rebel-4): 38 1886: Founding of Johnson & Johnson[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Johnson_%26_Johnson&action=edit§ion=3)] Robert Wood Johnson joined his brothers, [James Wood Johnson](/wiki/James_Wood_Johnson) and [Edward Mead Johnson](/wiki/Edward_Mead_Johnson), and created a line of ready-to-use sterile surgical dressings in 1886. They founded Johnson & Johnson in 1886 [[5]](#cite_note-bio_dictionary-5): 675 [[4]](#cite_note-Rebel-4): 38 with 14 employees, eight women and six men. [[4]](#cite_note-Rebel-4): 43 Johnson & Johnson opened its first factory building in the old Janeway and Carpenter factory on Neilson Street in New Brunswick, New Jersey. [[8]](#cite_note-8) They manufactured sterile surgical supplies, household products, and medical guides. [[9]](#cite_note-History-9) Those products initially featured a logo that resembled the signature of James Wood Johnson, very similar to the current logo. [[10]](#cite_note-10) Robert Wood Johnson served as the first president of the company. [[5]](#cite_note-bio_dictionary-5): 675 1887-1942: Early history[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Johnson_%26_Johnson&action=edit§ion=4)] The company sold medicated plasters such as Johnson & Johnson's Black Perfect Taffeta Court Plaster [[11]](#cite_note-11) and also manufactured the world's first sterile surgical products, including sutures, absorbent cotton, and gauze. [[12]](#cite_note-12) The company published "Modern Methods of Antiseptic Wound Treatment", a guide on how to do sterile surgery using its products, and in 1888, distributed 85,000 copies to doctors and pharmacists across the United States. [[13]](#cite_note-:3-13): 3-99 The manual was translated into three languages and distributed worldwide. [[13]](#cite_note-:3-13) The first commercial first aid kit was designed in 1888 to support railroad construction workers, who were often hundreds of miles from medical care. [[13]](#cite_note-:3-13) The kits included antiseptic emergency supplies and directions for field use. In 1901, the company published the Handbook of First Aid, a guide on applying first aid. [[13]](#cite_note-:3-13) In 1889, the company hired pharmacist [Fred Kilmer](/wiki/Frederick_Barnett_Kilmer) as its first scientific director, who led its scientific research and wrote educational manuals. [[13]](#cite_note-:3-13) Kilmer's first achievement as scientific director was developing the industrial sterilization process. [[13]](#cite_note-:3-13) He was employed at the company until 1934. [[13]](#cite_note-:3-13) Johnson & Johnson had more than 400 employees and 14 buildings by 1894. [[13]](#cite_note-:3-13) [[14]](#cite_note-14) In 1894, the company began producing Johnson's Baby Powder, the company's first baby product. [[9]](#cite_note-History-9) The company introduced the world's first maternity kit in 1894 to aid at-home births, called Dr. Simpson's Maternity Packet, presumably after Scottish [obstetrician](/wiki/Obstetrics) [James Young Simpson](/wiki/James_Young_Simpson). The kit included a washcloth; safety sterile sutures, sponges, and gauze; antiseptic soap; an obstetric sheet and ligatures; flannel to wrap the baby in; and a chart for keeping birth records. [[15]](#cite_note-15) [[9]](#cite_note-History-9) The products were later marketed separately, Maternity", instructional guide for mothers before and after delivery. [[18]](#cite_note-18) In 1904, the company expanded its baby care products with "Lister's Sanitary Diapers", a diaper product for infants. [[19]](#cite_note-19) During the [Spanish-American War](/wiki/Spanish%E2%80%93American_War), Johnson & Johnson developed and donated 300,000 packaged compressed surgical dressings for soldiers in the field [[4]](#cite_note-Rebel-4): 78 and created a trauma stretcher for field medics. The company donated its products in disaster relief efforts of the [1900 Galveston hurricane](/wiki/1900_Galveston_hurricane) [[4]](#cite_note-Rebel-4): 79 and the [1906 San Francisco earthquake](/wiki/1906_San_Francisco_earthquake). [[4]](#cite_note-Rebel-4): 81 Johnson & Johnson vaccinated all of its employees against [smallpox](/wiki/Smallpox) during the 1901 smallpox epidemic. The firm employed more than 1,200 people by 1910. [[20]](#cite_note-peril-20) Women accounted for half of the company's workforce and led a quarter of its departments. [[20]](#cite_note-peril-20) Robert Wood Johnson died in 1910, and he was succeeded as president of the company by his brother James Wood Johnson. [[4]](#cite_note-Rebel-4): 195 During [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I), Johnson & Johnson factories increased production to meet wartime demands for sterile surgical products. [[21]](#cite_note-21) [[22]](#cite_note-about_us-22) In 1916, the company acquired Chicopee Manufacturing Company in [Chicopee Falls, Massachusetts](/wiki/Chicopee_Falls,_Massachusetts), to meet demand. [[22]](#cite_note-about_us-22) [[4]](#cite_note-Rebel-4): 129 Near the end of World War I, the [1918 flu pandemic](/wiki/Spanish_flu) broke out. The company invented and distributed an epidemic mask that helped prevent the spread of the flu. [[23]](#cite_note-23) [[24]](#cite_note-universe-24) In 1919, Johnson & Johnson opened the Gilmour Plant near Montreal, its first factory outside of the United States, [[24]](#cite_note-universe-24) which produced surgical products for international customers. In 1924 the company's first overseas manufacturing facility was opened in [Slough, England](/wiki/Slough,_England). [[24]](#cite_note-universe-24) In 1920, Earle Dickson combined two Johnson & Johnson products, adhesive tape and gauze, to create the first commercial adhesive bandage. Band-Aid Brand Adhesive Bandages began sales the following year. [[24]](#cite_note-universe-24) [[4]](#cite_note-Rebel-4) In 1921, the company released Johnson's Baby Soap. [[25]](#cite_note-25) Named after its Massachusetts facility, Johnson & Johnson built a textile mill and company town, Chicopee, outside of Gainesville, Georgia. [[4]](#cite_note-Rebel-4): 170 In the 1930s, the company expanded operations to Argentina, Brazil, Mexico, and South Africa. [[26]](#cite_note-26) In 1931, Johnson & Johnson introduced the first prescription contraceptive gel marketed as Ortho-Gynol. [[27]](#cite_note-27) [Robert Wood Johnson II](/wiki/Robert_Wood_Johnson_II) became president of the company in 1932. [[4]](#cite_note-Rebel-4): 195 During The Great Depression Johnson & Johnson kept all its workers employed and raised wages by 5%. [[4]](#cite_note-Rebel-4): 191 In 1933, Robert Wood Johnson II wrote a letter to [Franklin D. Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt), calling for a federal law to increase wages and reduce hours for all American workers. [[4]](#cite_note-Rebel-4): 199 The company also opened a new facility in Chicago during that period. [[4]](#cite_note-Rebel-4): 191 Johnson wrote and distributed "Try Reality: A Discussion of Hours, Wages, and The Industrial Future" to persuade business leaders to follow his lead, advocating that business is more than profit and that companies have responsibilities to consumers, employees, and society. In "Try Reality", the section titled "An Industrial Philosophy" would later become the company's credo. [[4]](#cite_note-Rebel-4): 224 [[24]](#cite_note-universe-24) In 1935, Johnson's Baby Oil was added to its line of baby products. [[28]](#cite_note-28) [[29]](#cite_note-29) Both male and female Johnson & Johnson employees were drafted and enlisted during World War II. [[30]](#cite_note-30) [[31]](#cite_note-31) The company ensured no one would lose their job when they returned home. Robert Wood Johnson II was appointed head of the Smaller War Plants Corporation in Washington, D.C. His work ensured U.S. factories with under 500 employees were awarded government contracts. [[32]](#cite_note-32) [[33]](#cite_note-33) 1943: Credo and going public[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Johnson_%26_Johnson&action=edit§ion=5)] In 1943, as the company was preparing for its [initial public offering](/wiki/Initial_public_offering) (IPO), Robert Wood Johnson wrote what the company would call, "Our Credo", [[34]](#cite_note-34) a defining document that has been used to guide the company's decisions over the years. [[35]](#cite_note-35) The company completed its IPO and became a [public company](/wiki/Public_company) in 1944. [[36]](#cite_note-36) In 1943, [Vesta Stoudt](/wiki/Vesta_Stoudt) identified a need for waterproof tape for ammunition boxes in [World War Two](/wiki/World_War_II). She wrote to [Franklin D. Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt) with the idea; the president commissioned Revolite, a subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson at the time, to develop and manufacture a cloth-based adhesive tape. [[37]](#cite_note-37) 1944-1999: Acquisitions and international expansion[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Johnson_%26_Johnson&action=edit§ion=6)] In 1944, the company began selling [Johnson's Baby](/wiki/Johnson%27s_Baby) Lotion. The same year, the company established Ethicon Suture Laboratories. In 1947, G. F. Merson Ltd. was acquired to expand the company's suture business in the United Kingdom. The company was rebranded and absorbed into [Ethicon](/wiki/Ethicon). [[38]](#cite_note-38) Johnson & Johnson [Chairman of the Board](/wiki/Chairperson) Robert Wood Johnson published Or Forfeit Freedom in 1947. The book outlined that businesses need to develop [sustainable](/wiki/Sustainability) methods of using [natural resources](/wiki/Natural_resource) for the future of business and the planet. [[39]](#cite_note-39) In 1955, Ethicon developed a micro point reverse--cutting ophthalmic needle attached to the suture. Micro-point surgical needles and sutures allowed for advances in modern vision surgery. [[40]](#cite_note-40) [[41]](#cite_note-41) In 1956, the company open its first Asia-based operating company in the Philippines. [[42]](#cite_note-42) The following year, an operating company opened in India. [[43]](#cite_note-43) [[44]](#cite_note-44) [[45]](#cite_note-45) In 1959, Johnson & Johnson acquired McNeil Laboratories. [[46]](#cite_note-:0-46) A year later, the company sold Tylenol for the first time without a prescription. [[46]](#cite_note-:0-46) In the same year, Cilag Chemie joined Johnson & Johnson as Cilag. [[46]](#cite_note-:0-46) In 1961, Janssen Pharmaceutica was acquired by Johnson & Johnson. Janssen Pharmaceutica was founded in 1953 by Belgian scientist [Dr. Paul Janssen](/wiki/Paul_Janssen). [[46]](#cite_note-:0-46) In 1963, [Philip B. Hofmann](/wiki/Philip_B._Hofmann) succeeded Robert Wood Johnson as Chairman and CEO. He was the first non-Johnson family member to become chief executive. Hofmann also helped found the [Robert Wood Johnson Foundation](/wiki/Robert_Wood_Johnson_Foundation). [[47]](#cite_note-:1-47) In the same year, the Food and Drug Administration approved a synthetic hormone contraceptive pill, Ortho-Novum. [[48]](#cite_note-48) In 1965, Johnson & Johnson acquired Codman & Shurtleff. The acquired company produced neurovascular devices and neurosurgery technologies. [[49]](#cite_note-49) In 1968, the company developed the [RhoGAM](/wiki/Rho(D)_immune_globulin) Vaccine. The vaccine prevented Rh hemolytic disease in newborns. [[50]](#cite_note-50) In 1969, Ortho Diagnostics, a company subsidiary, launched the Sickledex Tube Test for detecting anemia. [[51]](#cite_note-51) The same year, the FDA approved the Johnson & Johnson arterial graft. [[52]](#cite_note-52) In 1971, the company launched Hapindex Diagnostic Test, a rapid [hepatitis B](/wiki/Hepatitis_B) test for blood donors. The test was developed to prevent the spread of hepatitis B through blood transfusions. [[53]](#cite_note-53) In the 1970s, Johnson & Johnson hired Henry N. Cobb from Pei Cobb Freed & Partners to design its new Headquarters. [[54]](#cite_note-54) The firm designed Johnson & Johnson Plaza across the railroad tracks from the older section of the Johnson & Johnson campus. [[55]](#cite_note-55) In 1973, [Richard Sellars](/wiki/Richard_B._Sellars) became Chairman and CEO of Johnson & Johnson. [[56]](#cite_note-56) In 1976, [James E. Burke](/wiki/James_E._Burke) became the company's Chairman and CEO. [[46]](#cite_note-:0-46) During Burke's tenure, he managed the 1982 Tylenol tampering incident. It became a case study on crisis management. Under his leadership, the company recalled 31 million bottles of Tylenol, relaunched the product with a triple tamper-evident seal, and urged consumers not to use if tampered with. These practices became the pharmaceutical and packaged food industry norm. [[57]](#cite_note-57) Johnson & Johnson opened operating companies in [China](/wiki/China) and [Egypt](/wiki/Egypt) in 1985. [[46]](#cite_note-:0-46) In 1987, [Acuvue](/wiki/Acuvue) [contact lenses](/wiki/Contact_lens) became the first disposable contact lenses available to consumers. The lenses lasted up to one week, reducing the cost of contact lenses. In the same year, the company launched One Touch, a blood glucose monitoring system. In 1989, [Ralph S. Larsen](/wiki/Ralph_S._Larsen) was appointed Chairman and CEO of the company. [[58]](#cite_note-58) After the [Dissolution of the Soviet Union](/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union), Johnson & Johnson expanded into eastern Europe. By 1991, the company had a presence in [Hungary](/wiki/Hungary), [Russia](/wiki/Russia), the [Czech Republic](/wiki/Czech_Republic), and [Poland](/wiki/Poland). [[59]](#cite_note-59) In the 1990s, the company acquired many familiar consumer health brands that made up the Johnson & Johnson family of companies. These acquisitions included [Clean & Clear](/wiki/Clean_%26_Clear), [Neutrogena](/wiki/Neutrogena), [Motrin](/wiki/Motrin), and [Aveeno](/wiki/Aveeno). [[47]](#cite_note-:1-47) Johnson & Johnson opened an operating company in [Israel](/wiki/Israel) in 1996. [[60]](#cite_note-60) In 1997, Johnson & Johnson acquired Biosense Webster. [DePuy](/wiki/DePuy_Synthes) was acquired by Johnson & Johnson in 1998, rolling it into the Medtech business group. [[47]](#cite_note-:1-47) 2000-present[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Johnson_%26_Johnson&action=edit§ion=7)] [William C. Weldon](/wiki/William_C._Weldon) was appointed Chairman and CEO of the company in 2002. [[61]](#cite_note-61) In 2003, Ethicon launched [Vicryl](/wiki/Vicryl) Plus Antibacterial Sutures. The products prevent post-surgery infection within stitches. In 2006, Johnson & Johnson acquired Pfizer's consumer healthcare business and merged it with its consumer healthcare business group. The acquisition added brands like [Listerine](/wiki/Listerine), [Bengay](/wiki/Bengay), and [Neosporin](/wiki/Neomycin/polymyxin_B/bacitracin) to the company's portfolio. [[62]](#cite_note-62) In the same year, Johnson & Johnson's Janssen Pharmaceuticals, launched [Prezista](/wiki/Prezista), a protease inhibitor for patients with failed previous HIV therapies. [[63]](#cite_note-63) [[64]](#cite_note-64) In 2008, Johnson & Johnson acquired [Mentor Corporation](/wiki/Mentor_(company)) for $1 billion and merge its operations into Ethicon. In 2009, the company acquired HealthMedia, later renamed to Health & Wellness Solutions and the Human Performance Institute. In October 2010, J&J acquired [Crucell](/wiki/Janssen_Vaccines) for $2.4 billion. The subsidiary operates as the centre for vaccines, within Johnson & Johnson pharmaceuticals business group. [[65]](#cite_note-65) In 2012, [Alex Gorsky](/wiki/Alex_Gorsky) became Chairman and CEO of Johnson & Johnson. [[66]](#cite_note-66) In November 2015, Biosense Webster, Inc. acquired Coherex Medical Inc. expanding the company's range of treatment options for patients with atrial fibrillation. [[67]](#cite_note-67) In 2017, Johnson & Johnson acquired Abbott Medical Optics from Abbott Laboratories for $4.325 billion, adding the new division into [Johnson & Johnson Vision](/wiki/Johnson_%26_Johnson_Vision) Care, Inc. in 2017. [[68]](#cite_note-68) The same year, Johnson & Johnson acquired [Actelion](/wiki/Actelion) in a $30 billion deal, the largest ever purchase by the company. After the purchase, Johnson & Johnson spun off Actelion's research and development unit, into a separate legal entity. [[69]](#cite_note-69) In July 2017, Johnson & Johnson Vision Care, Inc acquired [TearScience](/wiki/TearScience). In September 2017, the company acquired subscription-based contact lens startup Sightbox. In September of the same year Johnson & Johnson Medical GmbH acquired Emerging Implant Technologies GmbH, manufacturer of 3D-printed titanium interbody implants for [spinal fusion](/wiki/Spinal_fusion) surgery. [[70]](#cite_note-70) In March 2019, the FDA approved [esketamine](/wiki/Esketamine) for the treatment of severe depression, which is marketed as [Spravato](/wiki/Spravato) by Janssen Pharmaceuticals. [[71]](#cite_note-71) [[72]](#cite_note-72) In 2019, Johnson & Johnson announced the release of photochromic contact lenses. The lenses adjust to sunlight and help eyes recover from bright light exposure faster. The lenses contain a photochromic additive that adapts visible light amounts filtered to the eyes and are the first to use such additives. [[73]](#cite_note-73) In November 2020, Johnson & Johnson acquired Momenta Pharmaceuticals for $6.5 billion. [[74]](#cite_note-74) In January 2022, [Joaquin Duato](/wiki/Joaquin_Duato) became CEO of Johnson & Johnson. [[75]](#cite_note-75) In November 2022, Johnson & Johnson announced that it would acquire [Abiomed Inc](/wiki/Abiomed) for $16.6 billion. [[76]](#cite_note-76) The deal closed on December 22. [[77]](#cite_note-77) [[78]](#cite_note-78) Johnson & Johnson began the separation of their consumer healthcare business group in November 2021. [[79]](#cite_note-79) In September 2022, Johnson & Johnson chose [Kenvue](/wiki/Kenvue) as the new name for its Consumer Health business. Kenvue went public through an IPO in May 2023, with Johnson & Johnson maintaining a controlling stake of around 91 percent. [[80]](#cite_note-80) On July 24, 2023, Johnson & Johnson Launched an exchange offer to split-off Kenvue. [[81]](#cite_note-81) Following the completion of the exchange offer, Johnson & Johnson will retain approximately 9.5% of the outstanding shares of Kenvue common stock. [[82]](#cite_note-82) [ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Johnson_%26_Johnson&action=edit§ion=8)] Johnson & Johnson committed over $1 billion toward the development of a not-for-profit [COVID-19](/wiki/COVID-19) vaccine in partnership with the [Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority](/wiki/Biomedical_Advanced_Research_and_Development_Authority) (BARDA) Office of the [Assistant Secretary for Preparedness and Response](/wiki/Assistant_Secretary_for_Preparedness_and_Response) (ASPR) at the [U.S. Department of Health and Human Services](/wiki/U.S._Department_of_Health_and_Human_Services) (HHS). [[83]](#cite_note-Vecchione-83) [[84]](#cite_note-84) Paul Stoffels of Johnson & Johnson said, "In order to go fast, the people of Johnson & Johnson are committed to do this and all together we say we're going to do this not for profit. That's the fastest and the best way to find all the collaborations in the world to make this happen so we commit to bring this at a not-for-profit level." [[85]](#cite_note-85) [Janssen Medical Center](/wiki/Beth_Israel_Deaconess_Medical_Center) (BIDMC), is responsible for developing the vaccine candidate, based on the same technology used to make its [Ebola vaccine](/wiki/Ebola_vaccine). The vaccine candidate is expected to enter phase 1 human clinical study in September 2020. [[83]](#cite_note-Vecchione-83) [[86]](#cite_note-86) [[87]](#cite_note-87) Demand for the product [Tylenol](/wiki/Tylenol_(brand)) surged two to four times normal levels in March 2020. In response, the company increased production globally. For example, the Tylenol plant in Puerto Rico ran 24 hours a day, seven days a week. [[88]](#cite_note-88) In response to the shortage of ventilators, Ethicon, with [Prisma Health](/wiki/Prisma_Health), made and distributed the VESper Ventilator Expansion Splitter, which uses 3D printing technology, to allow one ventilator to support two patients. [[89]](#cite_note-89) Janssen COVID-19 vaccine[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Johnson_%26_Johnson&action=edit§ion=9)] In June 2020, Johnson & Johnson and the [National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases](/wiki/National_Institute_of_Allergy_and_Infectious_Diseases) (NIAID) confirmed its intention to start a clinical trials of J&J's vaccine in September 2020, with the possibility of Phase 1/2a human clinical trials starting at an accelerated pace in the second half of July. [[90]](#cite_note-90) [[91]](#cite_note-91) [[92]](#cite_note-92) On August 5, 2020, the [US government](/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States) agreed to pay more than $1 billion to Johnson and Johnson (medical device company) for the production of 100 million doses of COVID-19 vaccine. As part of the agreed-upon deal, the U.S. can order up to 200 million additional doses of SARS-CoV-2 vaccine. [[93]](#cite_note-93) In September 2020, Johnson & Johnson started its 60,000-person phase 3 [adenovirus](/wiki/Adenoviridae)-based vaccine trial. [[94]](#cite_note-94) The trial was paused on October 12, 2020, because a volunteer became ill, [[95]](#cite_note-95) but the company said it found no evidence that the vaccine had caused the illness and announced on October 23, 2020, that it would resume the trial. [[96]](#cite_note-96) [[97]](#cite_note-97) In April 2021, the company reported that its COVID-19 vaccine achieved $100 million sales in the first quarter, accounting for less than 1% of its total revenue. [[98]](#cite_note-98) [[99]](#cite_note-99) Patent on tuberculosis-treating drug, bedaquiline[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Johnson_%26_Johnson&action=edit§ion=10)] Johnson & Johnson holds a patent on the tuberculosis-treating drug [bedaquiline](/wiki/Bedaquiline), with secondary patents in at least 25 out of 43 countries with a high burden of tuberculosis blocking affordable generic versions of the drug, preventing millions of people from accessing the life-saving treatment. Though the patent was set to expire in many countries in 2023, Johnson & Johnson applied to extent the patent. [[100]](#cite_note-100) [[101]](#cite_note-101) Evidence suggests that company did so to maximize its profits through the monopoly on the drug, despite knowing that making affordable generic versions more widely-available would save millions of lives. In April 2023, the international medical humanitarian organization [Médecins Sans Frontières/Doctors Without Borders (MSF)](/wiki/M%C3%A9decins_Sans_Fronti%C3%A8res) demanded that Johnson & Johnson publicly commit to not enforce its secondary patents on the drug n all countries with a high burden of TB, and allow generic manufacturers to supply more affordable, quality-assured generic versions of this lifesaving drug to everyone, everywhere who needs it. On July 11, 2023, best-selling American author, YouTube video blogger, and philanthropist [John Green](/wiki/John_Green) began advocating via Twitter and YouTube for Johnson & Johnson to allow the patent on bedaquiline to expire so that millions of vulnerable people worldwide could access the life-changing treatment via generic brands. [[1]](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tMhgw5SW0h4&ab_channel=vlogbrothers) Green, a long-time public health advocate, led thousands of people in [Nerdfighteria](/wiki/Nerdfighteria) and from among his online following in contacting Johnson & Johnson to protest the company's efforts to evergreen the patent and hold the company responsible for violating its own credo under the Twitter hashtag #patientsnotpatents. [[2]](https://twitter.com/sportswithjohn/status/1679291184621944835?s=12) [[3]](https://twitter.com/johngreen/status/1678803865330647042?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Etweet) In response, Johnson & Johnson released a statement on Twitter in response, claiming that the company's patents have allowed them to ship 660,000 courses of SIRTURO (bedaquiline) to 159 countries and asserting that "the most significant barrier to treatment access for patients today is the fact that millions of patients with TB go undiagnosed every year." [[4]](https://twitter.com/JNJNews/status/1679168314986094592?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Etweet) The statement as Twitter users fact-checked the statement, refuting it with evidence of Johnson & Johnson's efforts to limit the lower pricing of bedaquiline and contrasting the millions of deaths from tuberculosis with the comparatively small number of SIRTURO courses provided to low-income countries. Business sectors[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Johnson_%26_Johnson&action=edit§ion=11)] The company's business is divided into two business sectors: Pharmaceuticals and Medtech. Johnson & Johnson Innovation, LLC (JJI) is a subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson. [[102]](#cite_note-102) JJI focuses on early-stage, [life science](/wiki/Life_science), and technology the company's [research and development](/wiki/Research_and_development) pipeline. [[103]](#cite_note-103) JJI provides startups with sourcing, infrastructure, and capital equipment at JLABS, financing & venture capital at JJDC, Inc., and collaborations leading to the potential development of medical device technologies, pharmaceuticals, and therapeutics. [[151]](#cite_note-151) [[152]](#cite_note-152) [[153]](#cite_note-153) Use of the Red symbol[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Johnson_%26_Johnson&action=edit§ion=27)] Johnson & Johnson registered the [Red Cross](/wiki/Red_Cross) as a U.S. trademark for "medicinal and surgical plasters" in 1905 and has used the design since 1887.
